messages: 4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:37): Hey guys, can anyone help me with a colorscheme installation?
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:38): cp colorscheme.vim .vim/colors
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:38): I did that, and I'm getting an odd error
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:38): sorry, that was overly brief :P
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:38): wait, I should put it in my home directory's .vim/ instead of $VIMRUNTIME/colors?
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:39): doesn't matter if it's a single-user machine
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (04:39): it does matter everytime you upgrade
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (04:39): because you have to move it
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:39): it depends where $VIMRUNTIME is
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (04:40): he doesn't know the difference, his VIMRUNTIME is clearly the default
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:40): if it's /usr/local/share/vim/vim70, then it does matter, but if it's C:\Program Files\Vim\vimfiles, it doesn't
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:41): I'm getting these errors: http://rafb.net/paste/results/zASxW441.html
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:41): I'm in Ubuntu Linux, BTW
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:41): aha
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:41): These colorschemes worked fine on my Windows XP install of GVIM... dunno what's going on
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:41): probly something simple
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (04:42): Tonren: bingo. they need to be in unix fileformat
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:42): <color.vim fromdos >color_new.vim
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (04:42): Tonren: edit it, :set ff=unix, and save
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (04:42): unix fileformat will work everywhere
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:42): tpope: Oh, so the creator created them intending to be used as Windows XP
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (04:42): Tonren: more likely, he created them not knowing any better, or forgot to fix it
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:43): okay, let's see... gvim *.vim, qq, :set ff=unix, :wnext, q, @q, ., ., ., ....
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:44): should only be that one file, no?
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:44): unlink: It's a bunch.  the dude made like 7
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:44): Ahhh, it worked
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:44): ugh, I forgot, he made empty lines be struck through
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:44): god, that drives me crazy
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:45): for i in *.vim; do <"$i" fromdos >"$i-new" && mv -i "$i-new" "$i"; done
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:45): unlink: already did it my way in vim.  ;P

4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:46): unlink: I'm a newbie bash scripter... actually the reason i whipped out Vim and had to get my colorscheme back is because I'm writing a bash script to add the song currently playing in MPC to a playlist
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (04:47): fromdos isn't standard anways
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:47): hardcore.
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:47): mpc --format '[%file%]' | sed '2,$d' >>playlist.m3u
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:47): man, I have been rocking out in Linux since I installed it
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:48): oh my god, dude, I totally ignored the format command
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:48): I was gonna do this crazy thing where I'd search for the song name and.. .well, it was really complex
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:48): reading man pages makes life too easy, right?
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:48): hahaha, bastard
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:48): I really need to get more familiar with sed, awk and grep
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:48): they're like tiny gods
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:49): could have also done head -1
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:49): wait, what would head -1 do?
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:49): or could have used the perl mpd binding
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:49): print the first line of its input
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:49): man head
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:50): I manned head, it wasn't really there.
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:50): it doesn't say that if you give it an integer, it'll treat it as -n . :P
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (04:50): what sort of archaic system are you on?
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:50): tpope: Archaic?!  I'm on Linux Ubuntu Dapper.
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:50): ah touche, it's indocumented
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:51): s/in/un
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:51): unlink: pwned.  well, not really.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (04:51): -n 1 would be preferred if you want to be portable
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:52): they're probably telling you something by not documenting that option
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:52): So sed '2,$d' ..... that starts on line 2, ok, but what does $d do?  i'm sifting for it in man sed, but..
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:53): man sed sucks
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:53): 2,$ is the range (line 2 till the last line)
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:53): d is the command
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:53): unlink: Apparently.  ahhh
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:53): it's just like :2,$d in vim
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:53): :help :d
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:53): "delete pattern space, start next cycle?"
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:53): hehehe
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:54): ahhh
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:54): Brilliant.
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:54): sed is not accidentally very similar to ex mode of vim
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:54): Everything in GNU is so interconnected; it's inspiring, in a way.
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:55): The fact taht you can pipe almost anything into anything is SO freakin powerful
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:55): cat /dev/urandom >/dev/fb0
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:55): What's a fubzero do?
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:55): what's a what do?
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:56): fb0 is the first framebuffer device on linux
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:56): hehe
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:56): linux devices are named after what they control
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:57): (although their names are simply a convenience, it's the device major and minor numbers that matter)
ded01cf47cdca62f9adcfd25cb1b3127 (04:57): what kind of retarded distro still uses /dev/fb0 instead of /dev/fb/0?
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:58): on my machine, /dev/fb0 is a symlink to /dev/fb/0
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (04:58): ciaranm: I think that might be the most hardcore thing anyone has ever said
ded01cf47cdca62f9adcfd25cb1b3127 (04:58): not by a long way
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:59): linux sux, bsd rox
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:59): l0lz
ded01cf47cdca62f9adcfd25cb1b3127 (04:59): bsd is dead
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (04:59): true, m$ pwnz
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (05:00): opendarwin is dead
ded01cf47cdca62f9adcfd25cb1b3127 (05:00): stillborn, rather
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (05:00): haha
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (05:02): I have no idea what the difference between Linux and BSD is.
a68dc5ae3ddabf401dc64c2b47e775b2 (05:03): stop by wikipedia
4539a9ac5a5c9d9cdf2ba2aa5562011b (05:03): unlink: No doubt.
